case_name: Abdul Rajak Murtaja Dafedar v. State

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated November 17, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1166 of 1967 and confirmation case No. 15 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated November 17, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1166 of 1967 and confirmation case No. 15 of 1967.

facts.text: The appellant was convicted under ss. 302, 307, 325 and 427, I.P.C. and also under S. 126 of the Indian Railways Act by the Additional Sessions Judge of Sangli in Sessions Case No. 9 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted under ss. 302, 307, 325 and 427, I.P.C. and also under S. 126 of the Indian Railways Act by the Additional Sessions Judge of Sangli in Sessions Case No. 9 of 1967.

facts.text: The appellant was sentenced to death under S. 302, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was sentenced to death under S. 302, I.P.C. No other sentence was awarded for the remaining offences.

facts.text: The prosecution case arises out of the derailment of Poona-Wasco Express train at about 4.40 in the early morning of October 10, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought by special leave from the judgment of the Bombay High Court. The prosecution case arises out of the derailment of Poona- Wasco Express train at about 4.40 in the early morning of October 10, 1966.

facts.text: The derailment occurred on the Vaddi bridge which is beyond Miraj station.

anchor.surface_text: The derailment occurred on the Vaddi bridge which is beyond Mraj station. As a result of this derailment, five bogies were capsized.

facts.text: As a result of this derailment, five bogies were capsized. Out of these five bogies, two went into the stream down below, two were on the slope and one on the track. In this incident ten persons died and a large number of other persons received grievous injuries.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this derailment, five bogies were capsized. Out of these five bogies, two went into the stream down below, two were on the slope and one on the track. In this incident ten persons died and a large number of other persons received grievous injuries.

facts.text: The charge against the appellant was that he had removed fish plates, nuts, bolts etc., of the rail joint near Vaddi bridge No. 215 on Miraj Mhaisal Railway track at Km. No. 743/9 and 10 between 4.05 a.m. and 4.50 a.m. in the early morning of October 10, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the appellant was that he had removed fish plates, nuts, bolts etc., of the rail joint near Vaddi bridge No. 215 on Miraj Mhaisal Railway track at Km. No. 743/9 and 10 between 4.05 a.m. and 4.50 a.m. in the early morning of October 10, 1966 with intent or knowledge that he was likely to endanger the safety of the persons travelling in the said train and he caused the Poona-Wasco express train No. 206 Dn. to be capsized at Vaddi and thereby companymitted murder knowingly causing deaths of 10 persons who were passengers in that train.

facts.text: The appellant Abdul Rajak Murtaja Dafedar was working at Miraj railway station as gangman in gang No. 13 of which Laxman Madar was the Mukadam or Gangmate and Bapu Sopana was the Keyman.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Abdul Rajak Murtaja Dafedar was working at Miraj railway station as gangman in gang No. 13 of which Laxman Madar was the Mukadam or Gangmate and Bapu Sopana was the Keyman.

facts.text: The area under this gang was from Km No. 741/3 to 747/5 covering a railway track of 4 miles or 6 km. Vaddi bridge falls within this area.

anchor.surface_text: The area under this gang was from Km No. 741/3 to 747/5 companyering a railway track of 4 miles or 6 km Vaddi bridge falls within this area.

facts.text: On October 9, 1966, an altercation took place between the appellant and Laxman.

anchor.surface_text: On October 9, 1966, an altercation took place between the appellant and Laxman. Laxman found the work of leveling and packing done by other gangmen except the appellant satisfactory and so Laxman asked the appellant to companyrect the defect.

facts.text: The appellant got irritated and took exception to the remark of Laxman and rushed towards him with a pick axe saying that he would break his head.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant got irritated and took exception to the remark of Laxman and rushed towards him with a pick axe saying that he would break his head. Laxman threatened to report the companyduct of the appellant to the Permanent Way Inspector and went away towards the tool box.

facts.text: Ramchand Sadre, P.W. 37, saw the appellant going on the track at 3 or 3.15 a.m. on October 10, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: According to prosecution case Ramchand Sadre, P.W. 37, saw the appellant going on the track at 3 or 3.15 a.m. P.W. 37 was serving as a Sainik of the Railway Protection Force at Miraj Railway Station.

facts.text: Goods train No. 239 arrived at Miraj Railway Station at 4.10 or 4.15 a.m. This goods train had passed the Vaddi bridge at 4.05 a.m.

anchor.surface_text: After the witness saw the appellant going along the track goods train No. 239 arrived at Miraj Railway Station at 4.10 or 4.15 a.m. This goods train had passed the Vaddi bridge at 4.05 a.m.

facts.text: The appellant let the goods train pass and approached the railway bridge at Vaddi with a spanner and removed the fish plates and the keys and jaws of the sleepers of the 18 rail of right hand side of the rail line.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant let the goods train pass and approached the railway bridge at Vaddi with a spanner and removed the fish plates and the keys and jaws of the sleepers of the 18 rail of right hand side of the rail line.

facts.text: On October 10, 1966 at 7 a.m. all the gangmen including the appellant collected at pole No. 744/4 for daily work but were asked by the police officers to be seated below the bridge as their statements were to be recorded.

anchor.surface_text: On October 10, 1966 at 7 a.m. all the gangmen including the appellant ,collected at pole No. 744/4 for daily work but were asked by the police officers to be seated below the bridge as their statements were to be recorded.

facts.text: On the same night at 8.30 p.m. near the spot of the accident the police dog Sheru of C.I.D., Poona, was brought. The dog identified the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the same night at 8.30 p.m. near the spot of the accident the police dog Sheru of C.I.D., Poona, was brought. The appellant, Laxman and five other persons were made to stand in a row facing the rail line in the presence of panchas.

facts.text: On October 17, 1966 the appellant offered to produce the spanner from the place where he had hidden it near the railway track.

anchor.surface_text: On October 17, 1966 the appellant offered to produce the spanner from the place where he had hidden it near the railway track. A memorandum of his statement was drawn in the presence of panchas.

facts.text: On October 29, 1966 the appellant made a confession before the executive magistrate, Ex. 130.

anchor.surface_text: On October 29, 1966 the appellant made a companyfession before the executive magistrate, Ex. 130.

facts.text: The appellant pleaded not guilty to the charges. He alleged that there was no altercation between him and Laxman and that he did not threaten Laxman with pick axe.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded number guilty to the charges. He alleged that there was numberaltercation between him and Laxman and that he did number threaten Laxman with pick axe.

facts.text: The trial court based the conviction of the appellant on 1 movement of the appellant on the day of the incident as stated by Ramchand Sadare P.W. 37 2 discovery of the spanner 3 the confession statement of the appellant made to the Executive Magistrate and 4 the identification of the appellant by the dog Sheru.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt based the companyviction of the appellant on  1  movement of the appellant on the day of the incident as stated by Ramchand Sadare P.W. 37  2  discovery of the spanner with which the nuts and bolts were removed,  3  the companyfession statement of the appellant made to the Executive Magistrate and  4  the identification of the appellant by the dog Sheru.

facts.text: The High Court accepted the prosecution evidence on all these points and affirmed the conviction of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the prosecution evidence on all these points and affirmed the companyviction of the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant was arrested on October 10, 1966 at 11 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that the appellant was arrested on October 10, 1966 at 11 p.m. and was kept in remand till October 18, 1966.

facts.text: The Supreme Court affirmed the judgment of the High Court and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we affirm the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dated 16/17, November, 1967 in Crl. A. No. 1116 of 1967 and dismiss this appeal.

arguments.claim: Confession voluntary as appellant in judicial custody for four days prior, warned, and had time to reflect

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the appellant was kept in jail custody for three days from October 25 to October 28, 1966 and on October 28 the Executive Magistrate made the preliminary questioning of the appellant, gave him a warning and sent him back to the District Jail at Sangli.

arguments.claim: Discovery of spanner at appellant's instance admissible and corroborates confession

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the Deputy Superintendent of Police and the two panchas has been accepted both by the trial court and the High Court. The discovery of the spanner at the instance of the appellant is an important circumstance which corroborates the confession of the appellant that he had removed the fish plates, nuts, bolts and the keys and jaws of the sleepers from the railway line on the alleged date.

arguments.claim: Dog tracking evidence akin to hearsay as reported by handler

anchor.surface_text: First, since it is manifest that the dog cannot go into the box and give his evidence on oath, and consequently submit himself to cross- examination, the dogs human companion must go into the box and report the dogs evidence, and this is clearly hearsay.

arguments.claim: Dog tracking evidence should be excluded due to dramatic impact out of proportion to value and unreliability

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, there is a feeling that in criminal cases the life and liberty of a human being should not be dependent on canine inferences. And, thirdly, it is suggested that even if such evidence is strictly admissible under the rules of evidence it should be excluded because it is likely to have a dramatic impact on the jury out of proportion to its value.

arguments.claim: Conviction under s.302 IPC sustainable as removal of fish plates etc. with knowledge likely to endanger safety causing deaths amounts to murder

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the appellant was that he had removed fish plates, nuts, bolts etc., of the rail joint near Vaddi bridge No. 215 on Miraj Mhaisal Railway track at Km. No. 743/9 and 10 between 4.05 a.m. and 4.50 a.m. in the early morning of October 10, 1966 with intent or knowledge that he was likely to endanger the safety of the persons travelling in the said train and he caused the Poona-Wasco express train No. 206 Dn. to be capsized at Vaddi and thereby committed murder knowingly causing deaths of 10 persons who were passengers in that train.

holdings.text: The confession Ex. 130 of the appellant was voluntary.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial Court and the High Court have upon an examination of all the circumstances reached the conclusion that the confession of the appellant was voluntary and we see no reason to take a different view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant in judicial custody for four days prior to recording, warned by magistrate, 24 hours to reflect; distinguishes Nathu v. State of U.P. and Swaran Singh v. State of Punjab; no evidence of inducement or coercion.

holdings.text: The discovery of the spanner at the instance of the appellant is admissible and corroborates the confession.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the Deputy Superintendent of Police and the two panchas has been accepted both by the trial court and the High Court. The discovery of the spanner at the instance of the appellant is an important circumstance which corroborates the confession of the appellant that he had removed the fish plates, nuts, bolts and the keys and jaws of the sleepers from the railway line on the alleged date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Panchanama and witness evidence accepted by lower courts; spanner found hidden at appellant's disclosure, matching confession details.

holdings.text: Evidence of dog tracking assumed inadmissible and not relied upon, as unnecessary given other conclusive evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We shall assume in favour of the appellant that the evidence of P.W. 72 and of the panchas with regard to the identification of the appellant by the tracker dog is not admissible. Even on that assumption we are of opinion that the rest of the prosecution evidence namely the confession of the appellant Ex. 130 and the discovery of the spanner conclusively proves the charges of which the appellant has been convicted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not necessary to decide admissibility; akin to hearsay, unreliable, dramatic impact disproportionate; other evidence sufficient.

holdings.text: Conviction under Sections 302, 307, 325, 427 IPC and Section 126 Indian Railways Act, including death sentence under Section 302 IPC, is sustainable and affirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Even on that assumption we are of opinion that the rest of the prosecution evidence namely the confession of the appellant Ex. 130 and the discovery of the spanner conclusively proves the charges of which the appellant has been convicted. For these reasons we affirm the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dated 16/17, November, 1967 in Crl. A. No. 1116 of 1967 and dismiss this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution evidence including voluntary confession, spanner discovery, PW37 sighting reliable; act of removing fish plates etc. with knowledge of likely deaths constitutes murder; lower courts' findings affirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Nathu v State of U.P.  1  in which the appellant was kept in the custody of C.I.D. Inspector on 7th August and the companyfession was recorded on 21st August. It was held that prolonged custody immediately preceding the making of the companyfession was sufficient, unless it was properly explained to stamp it as involuntary. No attempt was made in that case to explain the, prolonged custody. In the absence of such explanation it was held by the Court that the companyfession was number a voluntary companyfession.

precedents.cited_proposition: prolonged custody immediately preceding the making of the confession was sufficient, unless it was properly explained to stamp it as involuntary
precedents.cited_holding: prolonged custody immediately preceding the making of the companyfession was sufficient, unless it was properly explained to stamp it as involuntary. No attempt was made in that case to explain the prolonged custody. In the absence of such explanation it was held by the Court that the companyfession was number a voluntary companyfession

precedents.citation: Swaran Singh v. State of Punjab  2

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the material facts of the present case are number parallel to those of Swaran Singh v. State of Punjab  2  and the ratio of that case has numberapplication to the present case. It was also argued that the wife of the appellant used to go to the police station with her child and it A.I.R. 1956 S.C. 56. A.T.R. 1957 S.C. 637. was at her persuasion that the appellant had agreed to make the companyfession.

precedents.case_name: Swaran Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: voluntariness of confession in context of custody

anchor.surface_text: In R. v. Montgomery 2  a police companystable observed men stealing wire by the side of a railway line. They ran away when he approached them. Shortly afterwards the police got them on a nearby road. About an hour and half later the police tracker dog -was taken to the base of the telegraph pole and when he had made a few preliminary sniffs he set off and tracked companytinuously until he stopped in evident perplexity at the spot where the accused had been put into the police car.

precedents.cited_proposition: evidence of tracker dog tracking admitted as not hearsay but reporting movements of a tracking instrument
precedents.cited_holding: the evidence of the companystable who handled the dog on its tracking and reported the dogs reactions was properly admitted. The Court did number regard its evidence as, a species of hearsay but instead the dog was described as a tracking instrument and the handler was regarded as reporting the movements of the instrument

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we affirm the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dated 16/17, November, 1967 in Crl. A. No. 1116 of 1967 and dismiss this appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; judgment of the Bombay High Court affirmed upholding the conviction and death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial Court and the High Court have upon an examination of all the circumstances reached the conclusion that the confession of the appellant was voluntary and we see no reason to take a different view.
For these reasons we affirm the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dated 16/17, November, 1967 in Crl. A. No. 1116 of 1967 and dismiss this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the Deputy Superintendent of Police and the two panchas has been accepted both by the trial court and the High Court. The discovery of the spanner at the instance of the appellant is an important circumstance which corroborates the confession of the appellant that he had removed the fish plates, nuts, bolts and the keys and jaws of the sleepers from the railway line on the alleged date.
For these reasons we affirm the judgment of the High Court of Bombay dated 16/17, November, 1967 in Crl. A. No. 1116 of 1967 and dismiss this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We shall assume in favour of the appellant that the evidence of P.W. 72 and of the panchas with regard to the identification of the appellant by the tracker dog is not admissible.
